title: Activity Based Costing
content: Assigning and Allocating Costs# Product costs consist of direct materials, direct labor, and manufacturing overhead Easily traced and assigned to the product Direct material costs Direct labor costs Allocated to the product Manufacturing overhead costs Single Plant wide rate# A single plant wide rate is called the predetermined overhead allocation rate and is calculated before the period begins Multiple Department Rates# What if there are two departments with different allocation bases Overhead allocation base for Assembly Department is machine hours Overhead allocation base for the Software Department is direct labor costs Assembly Department# Software Deparmtnet# Total Cost# How is an activity-based costing system developed?# Activity based-management (ABM) Focuses on the primary activities the business performs Uses cost information to make decisions that lead to greater profits Activity-based costing (ABC) is the process of determining the cost of the activities as building blocks for allocating indirect costs to products and services Developing an activity-based costing system involves 4 steps 1. Identify activities and estimate their total indirect costs# - Examples of activities include: - Quality inspections - Inspect raw materials or finished products - Shipping - Setups - Purchasing - ![image.png](../assets/image_1762802626752_0.png) - 2. Identify allocation base for each activity and estimate total quantity of each allocation base# - ![image.png](../assets/image_1762802646920_0.png) 3. Compute the predetermined overhead allocation rate for each activity# - ![image.png](../assets/image_1762802658975_0.png) 4. Allocate indirect costs to the cost object# - ![image.png](../assets/image_1762802730769_0.png) - ![image.png](../assets/image_1762802774944_0.png) - ![image.png](../assets/image_1762802795625_0.png) Using activity-based management to make decisions?# Activity-based management uses activity based costs to make decisions that increase profits while meeting customer needs ABM decisions include Pricing and product mix Cost management Pricing and Product Mix Decisions# Pricing decision If the cost per unit changes, should the selling price also change? Product mix decision Compare the gross profit of two products and sell the product with the greatest gross profit to maximize total gross profit, considering limited production capabilities To determine which products are the most profitable, company controller recomputes total manufacturing costs and gross profit for standard and premium models Cost management decisions# Companies adopt ABC to get more accurate product costs for pricing and product mix decisions Value engineering reevaluates activities to reduce costs while satisfying customer needs Cross-functional teams including marketers, engineers, production personnel, and accountants, work together Target Pricing Target price is the amount customers are willing to pay for a product or service The target cost is the maximum cost to develop, produce and deliver the product or service and earn the desired profit Cost-based pricing The full product cost is the cost to develop, produce and deliver the product or service Desired profit is added to this full product cost to determine sales price Just in time management systems?# Reduces inventory costs Raw materials and finished goods are completed just in time for delivery to customers Cost of buying, storing and moving inventory can be significant to companies Using a quality management system?# System that helps managers improve the business’s performance by providing quality products and services is called a quality management system Goals of the system are: Improve performance Increase customer satisfaction Increase profit Four types of Quality costs Prevention costs- Costs incurred to avoid poor quality goods or services Appraisal costs- Costs incurred to detect poor-quality materials, goods, or services Internal failure costs- Costs incurred to correct goods or services before delivery to customers External failure costs- Costs incurred after delivery to the customer has occured How activity-based management be used in service companies?# Same steps as used for manufacturing companies Identify activities and estimate their total indirect costs Identify the allocation base for each activity and estimate the total quantity of each allocation base Compute the predetermined overhead allocation rate for each activity Allocate indirect costs to the cost object Just in time costing# Tracks costs after the units are completed It combines Raw Materials Inventory and Work in Process Inventory- Raw and In process inventory The conversion costs account combines direct labor and manufacturing overhead costs Recording Transactions title: Behavioral Finance
content:
Example behavioral finance graph# “I can calculate the motions of the heavenly bodies, but not the madness of men.”
Cognitive errors & emotional biases# Cognitive errors# Belief Perseverance (Core)# Description# Tendency to maintain a belief despite evidence that contradicts your beleif Example# Continuing belief in the honestly of a political candidate after clear evidence of corruption Confirmation Bias# Description# Seeking, interpreting, recalling information in a way that confirms pre-existing beliefs but ignoring conflicting data Example# Smoker only reading studies that downplay the health risks of smoking Conservatism bias# Description# Insufficiently revising beliefs in response to new evidence-sticking too closely to priors Key examples# An investor slightly downgrading a stock despite strong negative signals Favoring traditional candidates Keeping a feature in a product that users do not like/or isn’t working Representativeness bias# Description# Judging probability by similarity to a prototype, ignoring base rates or disconfirming evidence Key examples# Assuming a shy person is a librarian, not a salesperson despite base-rate odds Judging people based on their appearance Illusion of Control Bias# Description# Overestimating one’s ability to control or influence outcomes that are actually determined by chance or external factors-reinforcing belief in personal theories despite evidence of randomness Key examples# A gambler believing they can “will” a slot machine win or that rituals improve luck, even after repeated losses Or continuing to gamble believing that you will eventually win even though it is statistically unlikely Hindsight Bias# Description# Tendency to see past events as having been predictable (I knew along) after they occur, reinforcing overconfidence in initial beliefs and resisting revision Key example# After a market crash- “I knew it was going to crash”, even if the pre-crash predictions were optimistic Processing Errors# Anchoring and Adjustment Bias# Description# Over-relying on the first piece of information (the anchor) when making decisions, the insufficiently adjusting from it Key example# Asked “Is the Mississippi River longer than 500 miles?” then estimating 600 miles; if asked “longer than 5,000 miles?”, estimating 4,000 miles—even though actual length is —2,300 miles. Mental Accounting bias# Description# Treating money differently depending on its source, intended use, or mental account, rather than fungibility Key example# Refusing to use a $100 tax refund for groceries (seen as “extra”) but freely spending $100 from salary; or keeping a “vacation fund” separate from daily expenses. Framing bias# Description# Making different decisions based on how information is presented (gain vs loss frame), even if objective facts are identical Key example# 95% survival rate → people choose surgery; 5% mortality rate → people avoid it—even though both mean the same outcome. Availability Bias# Description# Judging likelihood or frequency by how easily examples come to mind, rather than actual data Key example# After seeing news about shark attacks, overestimating the risk of swimming; or fearing plane crashes more than car accidents due to vivid media coverage. Behavioral biases# Loss-Aversion Bias# Description# The pain of a loss is twice as much as the pleasure of a similar gain; therefore we prefer to avoid losses over acquiring gains Key example# Reusing to sell a stock down $1,000 in order to avoid realizing the loss, but not buying more of the stock when it is up $1,000 Disposition effect# Description# Selling winning investments to soon in order to lock in gains, and holding losing investments too long to avoid realizing losses Key example# An investor quickly sells a stock up 20% but holds one down 20% hoping it comes back Overconfidence Bias# Description# Overestimating one’s own knowledge, predictive ability, or control over outcomes Key example# A trader believing they can beat the market consistently despite average returns; or a driver claiming “I’m above average” (statistically impossible for most). Self-Control bias# Description# Prioritizing short-term gratification over long term goals due to impulsivity and a lack of discipline Key example# Spending a bonus on a luxury item instead of saving for retirement Eating dessert despite a diet plan Status Quo bias# Description# Preferring things to stay the same Resisting change even when a new option is better Key example# Refusing to sell a family heirloom for $5,000 even though you wouldn’t buy it for a lower amount Regret-Aversion bias# Description# Avoiding decisions that might lead to regret, even if rationally optimal Fear of being wrong Key example# Not investing in a stock that later surges or not selling a stock that crashes

title: Job Order Costing
content: Usage of Manufacturing Companies Use Job Order and Process Costing system?# Cost accounting systems measure, record, and report product costs Knowing unit costs helps managers Determine which products to produce Set sales prices that will lead to profits Determine how many products to produce Compute cost of goods sold for the income statement Compute the cost of inventory for the balance sheet Job costing system is an accounting system that accumulates costs by job Job is the production of a unique product or specialized service- one unit or a batch of units Process costing system is an accounting system that accumulates costs by process Used when companies manufacture identical units How do Materials and Labor costs flow through the Job Order costing system?# Companies use a job cost record to document the product costs for each job Materials# Purchasing materials Often stored for later usage Using direct materials in production Direct Materials Indirect Materials Materials purchased and materials used in production are usually different amounts Purchasing Materials# Using Materials# A materials requisition requests to transfer materials to the production floor Debit- Work in Process inventory or Manufacturing Overhead Credit- Raw Materials inventory When materials are received on the production floor, direct materials are recorded on the job cost record Labor# Most companies use electronic labor/time to track labor costs If a manual system is used, each employee completes a labor time record to track and assign direct labor and cost How do overhead costs flow through the Job Order Costing system?# Actual Overhead Costs Incurred- In addition to indirect materials and indirect labor, other overhead costs are incurred Depreciation on manufacturing plant and equipment of $20,000 Debit-Depreciation expense Credit-Accumulated Depreciation Plant utilities $7,000 Plant insurance of $6,000 Plant property taxes incurred by not yet paid of $5,000 Actual manufacturing overhead costs are not known until the end of the period Managers use a predetermined overhead allocation rate to allocate costs to jobs before the end of the period An allocation base links overhead costs to jobs Primary cost driver causes an increases or a decrease in the cost Common manufacturing company cost drivers are: Direct labor hours (labor intensive production enviroment) Direct labor cost (for labor intensive production enviroment) Machine hours (for machine intensive production environment) What happens when products are completed and sold?# After accumulating, assigning, and allocating the costs of direct materials, direct labor, and overhead jobs, a company Accounting for completion of jobs Accounts for the sale of jobs Adjusts Manufacturing Overhead at the end of the period How is Manufacturing overhead account adjusted?# Companies must adjust the Manufacturing Overhead account for any over or under allocation of overhead Underallocated overhead occurs when actual manufacturing overhead costs are more than allocated manufacturing overhead costs Overallocated overhead costs occur when the actual manufacturing overhead costs are less than allocated manufacturing overhead costs Journal entries# Schedule of Cost of Goods Manufactured# Data analytics in Accounting# For manufacturing companies, knowing the cost of production is vital to their sucess Managers can use the job order costing system to accumulate large quantities of data Data can be used in decision making How do Service companies use a Job order costing system?# Service companies do not have inventory or manufacturing costs Trace direct labor to jobs Allocate overhead costs to jobs Computing predetermined overhead allocation rate Allocating indirect costs to jobs, using predetermined overhead allocation rate Use the costing info to make pricing decisions

title: Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
content:
Introduction# About the Author# Major languages are Latin and French French was a language of International diplomacy English is emerging as a common lanuage Not viewed as well as the other Romance of the 1380s or possibly the 1390s Might have been Alternative Revival (throw back poem)? Unknown author \rarr (Gawain-poet or Pearl-poet) Author perhaps a court poet for the King Poem seems to come from the northwest Midlands, may have been from Cheshire, where Richard II often kept his court A bit further away from London There What does it mean to write the poem for the king? Four poems in the Cotton Nero ax. manuscript (three are religious) Pearl Patience Cleanness Sir Gawain and the Green Knight Most of old English poetry was alternative Some tie it into nationalism Poem is about nationalism Stresses in words and stresses of alliteration in the text Historical Context# The Hundred Years War (1337-1454)# - New French King Philip VI gives refuge to the Scottish King David II in 1334 - In 1337 confiscated the Duchy of Aquitaine (hereditary possession of English Kings) - Edward III claims the throne of France by right of birth (through his mother following death of her brother, Charles IV) - English win important early victories in France at Crecy (1346) and Poitiers (1356) - Its not as much of a continuous war, on or off periods Fitt 1# “Once the siege and the assault of Troy had ceased” (I) “So listen a little while to my tale if you will” (30) “the most chivalrous knights / the handsomest king” (51, 54) “at her place on the platform, pricelessly curtained I by silk to each side, and canopied across / with French weave and fine tapestry from the far east” (75-77)
Not beginning with the English story, but rather the story of their ancestors Back to the foundations “He [Arthur] brimmed with ebullience being almost boyish / / His blood was busy and he buzzed with thoughts” (85, 89) “a mountain of a man immeasurably high, I a hulk of a human from head to hips, / / I should genuinely judge him to be a half giant, / or a most massive man, the mightiest of mortals” (137-38, 140). “otherworldly, yet flesh / and bone” (198)
Presented as a youthful king Should be assumed to be a massive man/ half gaint Not quite a giant, but a massive man Almost supernatural but not quite Almost a king of Beowulf figure “They gaped and they gawked” (232) “were like statues in their seats, / left speechless and rigid, not risking a response” (241-42)
The audience is shocked “because your acclaim is so loudly chorused, And your castle and brotherhood are called the best, the strongest men to ever mount the saddle, the worthiest knights ever known to the world, both in competition and true combat, and since courtesy is championed here, I’m intrigued, and attracted to your door at this time.” (258-63).
Courtesy is paramount here The strongest, worthiest, the most chivalrous “Besides, / the bodies on these benches are just bum-fluffed bairns [children]” (279-80) “So who has the gall? The gumption? The guts?” (291) “So here is the House of Arthur,” he scoffed" (309).
There is a sense because he wants to offer the best, right, this challenge Knights and youth Throws down the contest with the axe Due to claim to be the best Looking for someone in the room to come forward and challenge him, but no one does “Then Arthur grips the axe, grabs it by its haft / and takes it above him, intending to attack” (330-31 “Gawain / now to his king inclines / and says, “I stake my claim. / This moment must be mine” (339-42).
Takes the axe and intends to attack Too prestigious for this sort of game This moment must be mine “you must solemnly swear that you’ll seek me yourself, that you’ll search me out to the ends of the earth to earn the same blow as you’ll dole out today in this decorous hall.” (394-97) “You’re charged with getting to the Green Chapel” (451). [oaths/reciprocity] “reap what you’ve sown” (452)
The terms are clear What is this contest Fitt 2&3# Laugh and grin with the green man gone \rarr almost a celebration The wall is hung on the wall as a sort of symbol of thier joy for men might be merry when addled with mead / but each year, short lived, is unlike the last” (497-98) (566-669) long, descriptive passage that diverges from the main narrative
A passage diverges from the main narrative just to tell us how to lose the passage of time Trying to go find the green knight Serves to Heighten tension Themes# The pentangle (the endless knot) \rarr Five fives Five senses Through the senses we can be tempted Five fingers Can resist temptation Five wounds Christs crucifiction Five joys Joys of Mary Five virtues The five joys of Mary \rarr part of the pentagonal Annuciation Coming birth of christ Nativity Birth of christ Resurrection Ressurected Ascension Ascension of Christ Assumption Five virtues Generosity (friendship) Fellowship (fraternity) Chastity (purity) Courtesy (politeness) Compassion (pity) “To find his equal on earth would be far from easy. Cleverer to have acted with caution and care, deemed him a duke—a title he was due— a leader of men, lord of many lands; better that than being battered into oblivion, beheaded by an ogre through headstrong pride. How unknown for a king to take counsel of a knight in the grip of an engrossing Christmas game.” (476-83) “He wanders near to the north Of Wales with the Isles of Anglesey off to the left. He keeps to the coast, fording each course, crossing at Holy Head and coming ashore in the wilds of the Wirral, whose wayward people both God and good men have quite given up on.” (697-702)
The person who was beheaded head falls and where is falls water springs up They have gone to this kind of dangerous wilderness “Father, hear me, / and Lady Mary, our mother most mild, / let me happen on some house where mass might be heard, / and matins in the morning” (753-56)
Is miserable and prays to god that things can get better “The knight had not seen a more stunning structure” (793). “Then he went on his way, but came back at once / with a group who had gathered to greet the stranger; I the drawbridge came down and they crossed the ditch / and knelt in the frost in front of the knight” (815-18). “Curtains ran on cors through red-gold rings, / tapestries from Toulouse and Turkistan / were fixed against walls and fitted underfoot” (858-59). “She was the fairest amongst them I / more glorious than Guinevere, or so Gawain thought” (943, 945)
The men who he encounters respect him The castle that he encounters is similar to Arthurs court mentioned at the beginning of the story A beautiful wife and an amazing castle “Once the master has gathered that his guest is Gawain he thinks it so thrilling he laughs out loud. All the men in the manor were of the same mind, being keen and quick to appear in his presences, this person famed for prowess and purity, whose noble skills were sung to the skies, whose life was the stuff of legend and lore. Then knight spoke softly to knight, saying “Watch now, we’ll witness his graceful ways, hear the faultless phrasing of flawless speech” (908-918)*
Told of how young the lord is Hear about his great reputation, partially out of courtesy The green knight arrives to see if it is true “The place you need is near, I two miles at most away” (1077-78). “Here’s a wager: what I win in the woods will be yours, / and what you gain while I’m gone you will give to me” (1106-7).
Given a great room and warm clothes This place is a dream The place that he wants to find is the Green Chapel Only 2 miles ahead Celebrate Christmas before he heads to the green chapel Another example of reciprocity “so through a lime-leaf border the lord led the hunt, / while snug in his sheets lay slumbering Gawain” (1178-79) “You’re tricked and you’re trapped!” (1210) “Gawain is a gentleman and remains on guard” (1282). “But I know that Gawain could never be your name” (1293).
Lord goes out on a hunt for deer while Gawain is sleeping in his bed Innocent kiss “Are you pleased with this pile? Have I won your praise?” (1379-80) “So he held out his arms and hugged the lord / and kissed him in the kindliest way—to my one profit, I though I’d gladly have given you any greater prize” (1388-91)
effictio- the dressing of the deer “Holds out his arms and hugged the lord”- “and kissed him” Other historical information# Medieval Canonical Hours Name Equivalent Matins 3 AM Lauds 5 AM/Sunrise Prime 6 AM Terce 9 AM Nones 3 PM Vespers 6 PM Eversong would have been a service of religious songs Told about this through a variety of liturgical books Fitts 3&4# “the biggest of wild boars has bolted from his cover” (1441) “So the day was spent in pursuits of this style, / while our lovable young lord had not left his bed” (1468-69)
Hunting the boar Involves the lord going out again in order to pursue the boar More parallels \rarr juxtaposition of the hunt Lord Gawain had not left his bed (passive creatures) Must confront the woman Cannot beat Gawain Man dedicated to his duty can not ignore “l encouraged you to kiss” (1489). “he hobbled away to hunker in a hole / by a stony rise at the side of the stream” (1569-70).
Retorts back to courtesy Kind of tension between them Going between this and the hunt for the boar Kind of a seduction Dodge her advances in order to get out of the situation The Boar is subdued by the Lord “Then, admiringly he handles the hog’s great head, / feigning fear to flatter the master’s feelings” (1633-34).
Irony when be being given the head of the boar since he was the one that did the beheading Has continued to kiss the lady “And so loving was that lady towards the young lord, / with stolen glances and secret smiles / that it muddled his mind and sent him half mad, / but to snub a noblewoman was not in his nature, / and though tongues might wag he returned her attention all night” (1657-62). “l have tested you twice and found you truthful. / But think tomorrow third time throw best’ (1679-80).
Gawain is struggling Cannot snub the noblewomen’s advances He is playing a fine line “Often, in the open, the pack tried to pounce, / then that crafty Reynard would creep into coved’ (1727-28) Why these animals?
The lord continues to hunt “in this manner through the mountains until midafternoon, / while our handsome hero snoozed contentedly at home” (1730-31). “She wore nothing on her face; her neck was naked, /and her shoulders were bare to both back and breast” (1740-41). “They talk with tenderness / and pride, and yet thei rplight / is perilous unless / sweet Mary minds her knight”
Set up these parallels We know that the lady is going to come again He is within the bed without being under the covers She is really pressing now Neck was naked and her shoulders were bare Passionate heat takes a hold in his heart He is in peril at this moment “There is no other one, / and won’t be for a while!” (1791 “Will you give me some gift—a glove at least” (1799). “She offers him a ring of rich, red gold” (1817). “so I give you my girdle, a less thing to gain” (1829). “Then fully and frankly he spoke of his sins” (1880).
He pushes back onto the lady \rarr this is not going to happen The lady offers him a ring of rich red and gold He refuses again He refuses other gifts that the lady offers him He intended to take neither gold nor girdle Like a fox how can he slip away out of this Wants to avoid this fate “Then red fur rips—Renyard / out of his pelt is prized” (1920-21). “His blue robe flowed as far as the floor, / his soft-furred surcoat suited him well” (1928-29). “He clasps him tight and kisses him three times” (1936).
Rise to the dead fox Tries to move past his relationship with the lady “So let him lie and think, in sight of what he sought. In time I’ll tell if tricks work out the way they ought.” (1994-97) “But our man bore the belt not merely for its beauty, / or the appeal of its pennants, polished though they were, / or the gleam of its edges which glimmered with gold, / but to save his skin when presenting himself’ (2037-40)
Time for Gawain to prepare to leave Takes the belt in order to save his skin “In that wilderness lives a wildman, the worst in the world, / he is brooding and brutal and loves bludgeoning humans” (2098-2099) “Green Church?” chunters the knight. / “More like the devil’s lair / where, at the nub of night, / he makes his morning prayer” (2185-88). “This is a haunted house—may it go to hell” (2195)
In the wilderness lives a crazy serial killer Brooding and brutal and loves to bludgeon humans Medieval audience would have said that he is trying to use his own sort of magic with this girdle Its similar to going to the devils lair/ a haunted house A disturbing place A soulless spot “that grinding is a greeting. / My arrival is honored with the honing of an axe” (2205-6). “Call yourself good Sir Gawain?” (2270). “it skewed to one side, just skimming the skin / and finely snicking the fat of the flesh / so that bright red blood shot from the body to earth” (2311-14).
A camoflauge man Pulls out an axe The blade has been sharpened by this giant of a man He was not afraid The same sort of insults that he had hurled at Arthurs court He runs away and then his horse is right there This is as one of Arthurs male kin becomes the king He is facing this Recognizes his own failings and takes off the green girdle He realizes the fate that he was trying to avoid anyway He has one more chance to do the right thing I must take this off before you take your swing at me “Do you walk the walk as well as talk the talk” Knows that his death is coming The threes- three days of hunting, three days of seduction, three days of exchange “my first strike fooled you—a feint, no less— not fracturing your flesh, which was only fair in keeping with the contract we declared that first night, for with truthful behavior you honored my trust and gave up your gains as a good man should. Then I missed you once more, and this for the morning when you kissed my pretty wife then kindly kissed me. The third time, though, you strayed, and felt my blade therefore.” (2345-49, 2356-57) “But a little thing more—it was loyalty that you lacked: / not because you’re wicked, or a womanizer, or worse, / but you loved your own life; so I blame you less” (2366-68). “By confessing your failings you are free from fault” (2391 “All wrecked and ruined by their wrongs; if only / we could love our ladies without believing their lies.” (2420-21
We want to save our lives as humans Cannot be blamed for his life actions \rarr and the actions of the women that seduced him “as a sign of my sin—I’ll see it as such / when I swagger in the saddle—a sad reminder / that the frailty of his flesh is man’s biggest fault” (2433-35). “In my manor lives Morgan la Fay” (2446) “To put pride on trial and to test with this trick / what distinction and trust the Round Table deserves” (2157-58).
A touch of filth taints his frame Always keep him humble when he is swaggering in the saddle Finds some humility Tests them to see if their reputation is true Wants to undermine her brother again We go back to the beginning of the text “He grimaced with disgrace, / he writhed in rage and pain. / Blood flowed towards his face / and showed his smarting shame” (2501-4). “The king gave comfort, then laughter filled the castle” (2513).
Another sort of confessional mode Gawain was not killed by the Green Knight because he was so great The girdle becomes a sign of brotherhood We go back to the beginning of the text and the assault on Troy The motto: “Hony Soyt Qui Mal Pence” (“Shame to him who thinks eviol of it”) The motto of the order of the girdle This was a royal society of King Edward III We still have this today, and you sometimes see royals wearing clothes from the order of the Gartle Overall Themes# The Girdle# To Arthurs Knights: Gawain’s survival Loyalty to brothers Overcoming adversity Gawain’s victory To Gawain: Sign of sin Sign of Human nature A failure of his knightly code Repetition# Gender? Who is in charge? Is Morgan’s test noble or treacherous? Do Arthur and his knights “get” the message of the “blazon of blame” We also begin and end in the same place Not aware of Gawain’s failures The Monster Stands at the Threshold of Becoming# “Monsters are our children” Monsters ask us how we perceive our world and how we have misrepresented what what have attempted to place” The beg us to reconsider our cultural disparities of economics, gender and sexuality How do the people in the court react to the presence of the monster in the court Other# What does Arthur expect of the world for himself? What is the norm for the king and ruler? How does the Arthurian court misperceive its own place in the world? What gender norms are set up by the poem and where does it radically veer from these expectations? What is the difference between power and and oppression? What about between confidence and pride? What is the reason for the Green Knight in the first place?

title: The Mabinogion
content:
The Mabinogion Branch 1# Introduction# White book of Rydderch (1350) Red book of Hergest (1382-1410) 4 branches probably by one author Other stories by many authors Might have been a court text Lady Charlotte Guest (1812-1895) Translated the tales into English in the mid-nineteenth century Gave the text its names: Mabingion Mab = son Songs of the sons Subsequent translations of the story into other languages Three stories correspond to famous romances by the French poet Chretien de Troyes (also possibly a court poet) Not much known about the writer Not simply the written version of oral tales, product of slow development of oral tales that were part of the collective memory Might have also combined many different smaller stories into one larger one King Arthur appears in five of the stories Early Latin Histories# Gildas# - Gildas (died in 570)- A British Monk who wrote *De excidio et conquestu Britanniare* (On the destruction and conquest of Britain) - Mentions the Battle of Mt. Badon (Mons Badonicus) fought around 500 CE - Ambrisius Aurelianus (Possibly Arthur) is a resistance leader of the Britons - Britons fight against the invading Saxons “…a gentleman who, perhaps alone of the Romans, had survived the shock of this notable storm: certainly his parents, who had worn the purple, were slain in it. His descendents in our day have become greatly inferior to their grandfather’s excellence.” - Parents who wore the purple (symbol of Rome) - Britons deserved this conquest
Nennius and the Annales Cambriae# - Nennius is a ninth-century Welsh monk - Writes Hsitoria Brittonum of "Arthur" the Christian *dux bellorum*who died at Mount Badon - Nennius notes the story of Vortigens tower and a boy, Ambriosus (Merlin) who explains the towers failure - Merlin is mysterious in his Answer - Symbolism of the dragon, especially in Wales - *Annales Cambriae* covers the years between 533 to 970 CE - Also the battle of Carmlann/Camblan in 539 CE between Arthur and Medraut (Mordred) Arthurs Stone in Camelford# - ![Arthur's Stone In Camelford](../assets/image_1764458485670_0.png) LATINI IACIT FILIUS MA….RI - Roman son of unknown - May have been the site of the Battle of Ricer Camblan
Medieval Wales# - ![Map of Medieval Wales](../assets/image_1764458561190_0.png) - 4 Kingdoms - Smaller areas inside the Kingdoms The Mabinogion# A text of Welsh culture and nationalism? The Normans had settled extensively in Wales and on the borders (the marches) between Wales and England after the Norman Conquest of England in 1066 In 1282, last Welsh King Llewellyn ap Gruffudd was killed and therefore the English basically conquered Wales They speak English and Welsh now Constant awareness of the National language Subsumed their culture Welsh Language blended into the English Culture Multiple Kingdoms combined under one rule The First branch# Prince Pwyll of Dyfed# - Then a rider came up to him and spoke to him like this: “Sir, I know who you are, but I will not greet you” “Sir, if I have done wrong, I will redeem your friendship” - White dogs with red earsDogs have captured a stag (deer) - Poole drives them off so his own dog can have the carcass of the deer - How can he repay the stranger

content:
** Unknown if Homer was one person or multiple May have inserted himself into his works as a type of self-portrait The Illiad Exists within 900 year space- most likely originally transcribed from oral history Transcribed approx 1 century after conception 16,000 lines long and composed 10 years before war between the Greeks and the Trojans. The Trojan war This war took place approx 4 years before the piece was written We start in the middle of the war Talks of the flood-almost like in Gilgamesh Couple spared in the flood and tasked with repopulating the earth through throwing stones (the bones of the earth) Troy is the western coast of Turkey Several layers have been excavated in this region discovering cities (9) Some evidence of war in this region from excavations The Hittite kingdom was located near the East of the Troy - can easily make cultural references/connection The Trojan war is started by the Judgement of Paris in which he chooses Aphrodite for love over two other Goddesses, Athena and Hera/ Paris seduced Helen, wife of Spartan Lord Menelaus. Menelaus seeks the aid of his brother Agamemnon. The content of the poem centers around Achilles, the greatest warrior of Agamemnon’s forces Angered the god Apollo by kidnapping Chryseis- the daughter of the high priest Chryses Forced to give up this woman, Agamemnon takes Achilles concubine Briseis in return, angering Achilles and provoking the warrior to “sit out” the war. He will return Achilles is accidentally killed Tension in this poem is that of the immortality of the gods and the mortality of the humans Achilles must reconcile himself to his own mortality Gods have to recognize just how much they’ve become- involved and immersed in human activity Gilgamesh and the Iliad have many similarities The Trojan horse The Odyssey Multiple narratorial perspectives, Odysseus tells his story in the first person in the middle. Dactylic Hexameter is a line of poetry with six metrical feet (one strong stress and two weak stresses) Major spaces: The main hall of Odyseeus kingdom Coming of age, growing old The collateral of war Wit and intellect over sheer fore Arbitrary acts of the gods and the powerlessness of humanity The Odyssey# Books 1-8# We start with summary of the whole: “He came to see / many people’s cities, where he learned their customs, / while on the sea his spirit suffered many torments” (1.3-5)] Almost like a muse We begin with an assembly of the gods, with Zeus and Athena speaking (Athena loves Odysseus for his cunning and his battle prowess) Zeus: “How could I forget godlike Odysseus, / pre-eminent among all mortal men for his intelligence and offerings / to the mortal gods” (1.66-68) Some linkage to the Illiad The gods will send Hermes, the messenger god, to Calypso, who holds Odysseus on her island (he’s been there seven years) Athena goes to Ithaca, to Odysseus’ palace where his son, Telemachus must entertain suitors to his mother (vying for her hand in marriage with Odysseus gone so long and presumed dead). Note the **hospitality **of Telemachus to the disguised goddess; hospitality is a significant theme in this text, so obsessed with feasting! Notice the contrast between Telemachus and the suitors. Notice too how the bard Phemius performs a song of Achaeans returning from Troy (but Penelope stops him from singing that “painful song” (1.276). Odysseus is a poor young man Hospitality is a central theme of the text and the culture as a whole The idea that when aiding a stranger, you actually might be aiding a god or gods in disguise- you may be rewarded for your actions- so be kind Telemachus is angry with all the suitors- Athena advises Telemachus to sail off and seek the word of his father (King Nestor in Pylos and the to Menelaus in Sparta) ““If you think it’s better and would prefer / that one man’s livelihood should be consumed / without paying anything, I’ll call on / the immortal gods to see if mighty Zeus / will bring about an act of retribution” (1.319-23)” “Telemachus spoke, then threw the scepter on the ground / and burst out crying” (2.52-53). Wily Penelope quote about the suitors- sounds similar to her husband Odysseus “you [suitors] must wait, / although you are keen for me to marry, / till I complete this cloak—for if I don’t, / my weaving would be wasted and in vain” (2.74-77) [but, after four years, she is betrayed by one of her women] Female characters are shown throughout the text weaving (including Athena)- a metaphor for how the narrative of the story is being shaped and spun over time Betrayed by a female servant who thus ends her resistance to the suitors (cant stop them) Athena roams Ithaca in disguise as Telemachus to recruit sailors for him in order to ensure that he is able to depart in a swift manner In Book 3 (omitted from your books), Telemachus will sail to Peleponnese (southern Greece) and journey by land to the city of Pylos where he will be entertained by his father’s old comrade, King Nestor. The King offers his own account of the battles at Troy and his return home to Pylos. The King will send Telemachus on, further, to Sparta to see Menelaus. Nestor’s son, Pisistratus (same name as later Athenian ruler) will accompany Telemachus. Telemachus compares the Hall of Menelaus to Zeus’s kingdom- and is corrected by Minnelaus: “No man alive could rival Zeus, dear boys, / with his everlasting palace and possessions” (4.87-88). Meleanus grieves for Odyseus and recognizes Telemachus by his resemblance to his father Helen’s and Menelaus’ account of Odysseus sneaking into Troy as a beggar and, then, the Trojan Horse: “We heard you [Helen] call. / Two of us—Diomedes and myself—were eager to get up and charge outside / or else to answer back from where we sat, in side the horse. But Odysseus stopped us—/we wished to speak, but he held us in check” (4.86-90) Helen admits that she might have been drugged in Troy We are reminded of the characters own mortality Athena appeals to the gods to aid Odysseus, who is still trapped on the island with Calypso and has been for 7 years. Athena describes the ambush that is being set for Telemachus. Hermes goes to Calypso to tell her that Odysseus must leave the island. Further establishes the theme of mortality vs immortality Odysseus sits regularly by the sea “his eyes always full of tears / because he was squandering his sweet life, mourning / for his return” (5.100-103).
Odysseus is Desperate for immortality
Monsters stand at the threshold of becoming “Monsters ask us how we perceive our world and “how we have misrepresented what we have attempted to place.” Odysseus starts to embrace his humanity and mortality Odysseus has to leave the island and must build his own boat in order to leave it Reminded of what it means to be a mortal in the realm of the gods However, Poseidon (Sea god) makes his journey difficult and Odysseus ends up washed up on the the shores of Paheacia “Here’s trouble! In this country I have reached, what are the people like? Are they violent and untamed, without a sense of justice? Or are they kind to strangers? In their minds do they fear the gods?” Book 7: Odysseus appears with the queen of the Phoenicians, Arete, and her husband King Alcinous Oyssedeus asks for kindness from the queen Another example of hospitality and sanctuary Alcinous: “If he’s a deathless one come down from heaven, / then gods are planning something different. / So far they’ve always shown themselves to us / in their true form” (7.78-80) They think that Ossyedus may have been sent from the gods However, Odysseus explains that he is mortal and not a god “I’m like mortal men. Indeed, I could recount a longer story, all those hardships I have had to suffer.” (To Alcinous) “After they enjoyed their heart’s fill of food and drink, the minstrel Demodocus, inspired by the Muse, sang about the glorious deeds of warriors, that story, whose fame had climbed to spacious heaven, about Odysseus and Achilles, son of Peleus, when, at a lavish feat in honor of the gods, they fought each other in ferocious argument” (8.34-40) Get a glimpse into the Greek Culture Another feast occurs between Aphrodite and and Ares which Hephaestus (Vulcan) learns about and is embarrassed and angry ““Nasty deeds don’t pay. / The slow one overtakes the swift just as / Hephaestus, slow as he is, has caught Ares, / although of all gods who hold Olympus / he’s the fastest one there is. Yes, he’s lame, / but he’s a crafty one” (124-29). The tortoise and the hare type of situation “He sang about the various ways those warriors / laid waste that lofty town [Troy] and how Odysseus, / like Ares, god of war, and noble Menelaus / went to the home of Deiphobus [Trojan prince], where, he said / Odysseus battled in the most horrendous fight, / from which he then emerged at last victorious” (8.249-54) Omitted text from my edition: “That was the song the famous harper sang / but great Odysseus melted into tears, / … / as a woman weeps, her arms flung around her darling husband, / a man who fell in battle, fighting for town and townsman, / trying to beat the day of doom from home and children. / Seeing the man go down, dying, gasping for breath, / she clings for dear life, screams and shrills—/ but the victors, just behind her, / digging spear-butts into her back and shoulders, / drag her off in bondage, yoked to hard labor, pain, / and the most heartbreaking torment wastes her cheeks. / So from Odysseus’ eyes ran tears of heartbreak now.” Oyssedus ponders his actions, killing,etc. Book 9: Odysseus becomes the bard and the storyteller “now I’ll speak / of the unhappy journey back which Zeus / arranged for me when I returned from war” (9.29-30) The Cicones (failure of his men to find moderation in their savagery and drunkenness) After leaving Troy, Odysseus and her men aim to get more spoils and more goods and material wealth in order to take home Heading to Immarus Plundering artifacts from countries Countries fight against Odysseus Crew ends up off course and in the land of the Lotus-eaters They manage to get away unharmed Questions: What does it mean to remember? What does it mean to forget? What is necessary to keep/lose? Questions of history and its making History has many flows Crew then ends up in the land of the Cyclopes- Takes 12 companions to seek hospitality from the locals who lead them to a cave where Polyphemus live “No man” Tricks the other cyclops “From the cave mighty Polyphemus roared: ‘Nobody is killing me, my friends, / by treachery, not using any force”’ (9.403-4). “He stretched out his arms, / attempting to catch anyone who tried / to escape there with the sheep” (9.415-17).” Polyphemus kills 2 of the men and eats them In order to escape, they must have Polyphemus open the door to the cave so that they can escape Get him drunk- They blind him with a stick and he is therefore unable to find Odysseus Odysseus abuses verbally the Polyphemus (Poseidon’s son)- makes Poseidon hate Odysseus The cyclops; “They don’t grow / any plants by hand or plough the earth, / but put their trust in the immortal gods, / and though they never sow or work the land, / still every kind of crop springs up for them” (9.92-96). “Each one of them / sets out laws for his own wives and children, / and they shun all dealings with each other” (9.101-103). “He avoided others / and lived alone, away from all the rest, / a law unto himself, a monster, made to be a thing of wonder, not like a man, / who survives by eating bread, no, more like / a soaring wooded mountain standing there / to view in isolation from the rest” (9.145-51 ). “l told the rest of my trustworthy crew / to stay there beside the ship and guard it, / while I selected twelve of my best men / and went off to explore. I took with me / a goatskin full of dark sweet wine” (9.152-55). “l was keen / to see the man in person and find out / if he would show me hospitality (9.180-82). “We’re here / as suppliants to you, and Zeus protects / all suppliants and strangers—as god of guests, / he cares for all respected visitors” (9.218-21 ). Another example of the theme of hospitality Men are brash to assume that the host will agree to their indulgence Odysseus escaped through hanging onto the bottom of the sheep Another instance of Odysseus being mortal, cannot compete with the might of a god such as Poseidon Odysseus travels to Aeolia Aeolus gives Odysseus a bag of ox hide Unknown why he did this In reality this is the “bag of winds” They can see Ithaca- Odysseus falls asleep The others on the boat open the sack in order to see what is in it (they seemed to believe that it was treasure) The winds and seas push the boat back to Aeolia King is furious- no lenience “Of all living mortals, you are the worst— so you must leave this island with all speed. It would violate all sense of what is right if I helped out or guided on his way a man the blessed gods must hate. So leave. You’re here because the deathless gods despise you.” “Once they heard his [Antiphates] call, / the mighty Laestrygonians poured out, / thronging in countless numbers from all sides—/ not like men at all, but Giants” (131-34). They encounter man-eating giants called Laestrygonians Trapped the 12 ships- only Odysseus ship escaped They then encounter Circe and her island-turns a party of men into pigs- one escapes to warn the others Hermes gives him the antidote to Circe’s powers- makes Circe vow not to plot or take revenge against his crew. The Pigs are then turned back into men “Inside their pens they wept. / Circe threw down some feed in front of them— / acorns, beech nuts, and cornel fruit—the stuff / pigs eat when they are wallowing in mud” (10.217-220). “Take a remedial medicine with you, / and go to Circe’s house. It will protect you” (10.239-40). “l found my trusty comrades at the ship / lamenting sadly, shedding many tears. / Just as on farms calves frisk around the herd / when cows, having had their fill of grazing, / return back to the yard—they skip ahead, / and pens no longer hold them, as they run, / mooing in a crowd around their mothers, / that’s how my companions, once they saw me, / thronged around” (378-83) Odysseus and crew go to the shores of the underworld Perform a sacrifice which brings the spirits of the dead to drink the blood Also includes Odysseus aunt Claire Revealed that she died from the grief of his absence The Prophet Tiresias comes with the spirits Tiresias offers a grim future for Odysseus: “a god will make your journey bitter” (11.66) but he offers some hope and a warning: “If you leave [the cattle and rich flocks of Helios the sun god] unharmed and keep your mind / on your return, you may reach Ithaca” (71-72). Further, he tells Odysseus: “There’ll be trouble at home—insolent men / eating up your livelihood and wooing / your godlike wife by giving courtship gifts” (11 . 79-81 ). “Your death will come / out of the sea, such a gentle passing, / when you are bowed down with a ripe old age, / and your people prospering around you” (100-3). Another relationship between the mortal and the immortal “Odysseus sees a procession of military heroes and women including Ajax, Agamemnon, and Epicaste (Jocasta), the wife/mother of Oedipus. He sees other mythological figures like Tantalus and Sisyphus. Most significant, he meets Achilles.” “Before now, / while you were still alive, we Achaeans / honored you as we did the gods. And now, / since you’ve come down here, you rule with power / among those who have died. So Achilles, / you have no cause to grieve because you’re dead” (11.330-35). Achilles responds: Don’t try to comfort me about my death, / glorious Odysseus. I’d rather live . working as a wage-laborer for hire / by some other ma, one who had not land / and not much livelihood, than lord it over all the waster dead” (11.337-42) Circe warns the returned Odysseus of his next obstacles, the sirens and later, the Scylla and Charybdis. Then will arrive at Helio’s island, Thrinacia, where he’ll find the cattle and sheep not meant to be interfered with. The Sirens: “No man has ever rowed his black ship / past here without attending to our songs, / sweet-voiced melodies sung from our own lips. / That brings him joy, and he then goes away / a wiser man, for we two understand / all the misfortunes faced by Trojans and Achaeans” (12.154-60). Must also make it past the 6 headed Hydra To prevent the men from hearing the sirens and falling victim to them, beeswax is put into the men’s ears Scylla and Charybdis: “l did not mention Scylla—for she was / a threat for which there was no remedy—in case my comrades, overcome with fear, / stopped rowing and huddled up together / inside the boat” (12.191-95). “When we saw Charybdis, we were afraid / we’d be destroyed. Then Scylla snatched away / six of my companions, right from the ship / … / They cried and screamed, calling me by name / on final time, their hearts in agony” (12.209-11 , 216-17). Lost six of the men on the boat to the Hydra Men are tired and do not want to continue on, and despite Odysseus not agreeing, land the ship on the island of Thrinacia At Thrinacia, observing Helios’ cattle and sheep: “Shipmates, / let all of you now swear this solemn oath— / if by chance we find a herd of cattle / or a large flock of sheep, not one of you / will be so overcome with foolishness / that you will kill a cow or sheep” (12.237-42). “Once what we had stored / inside our ship was gone, they had to roam, / scouring around for game and fish and birds, / whatever came to hand” (12. 270-73). “The gods / immediately sent my men bad omens— / hides crept along the ground, while on the spits / the meat began to bellow, and a sound / like cattle lowing filled the air” (12.358-62) Helios takes his revenge, conjures a storm that wipes out all of the crew on the deck of the ship. Odysseus escapes by taking hold of a branch of a tree above the whirlpool swallowing the ship Reprisals: “All at once, West Wind whipped up / a frantic storm—the blasts of wind snapped off / both forestays on the mast, which then fell back, / … / In the stern part of the ship, the falling mast / struck the helmsman on his head, caving in / his skull, every bone at once. Then he fell, / like a diver, off the boat. His proud spirit / left his bones. Then Zeus roared out his thunder / and with a bolt of lightning struck our ship. / The blow from Zeus’s lightning made our craft / shiver from stem to stern and filled it up / with sulphur smoke. My men fell overboard / and rode atop the waves” (12.375-88). I was guided to Ogygia by the gods, / the island where fair-haired Calypso live” (12.420-21). Odysseus is returned to Ithaca by the Phaeacians as he sleeps (Book 13) Does not initially recognize his homeland Athena: “Stranger, you must be a fool, or else come / from somewhere far away, if you must ask / about this land. Its name is not unknown— / not at all—many men have heard of it. Ithaca is well known, even in Troy, / a long way from Achaean land, they say” (13.80-85). “I’ll tell you what Fate has in store for you. / You’ll find harsh troubles in your well-built home. / Be patient, for you must endure them all” (104-6). “she touched him with her staff. / She wrinkled the lovely skin on his supple limbs / and took the dark hair from his head” (13.152-54) Book 14 Meets Eumeaus, the swineherd, a slave that is the most loyal to him Still remains committed to Odysseus “It would be wrong, / stranger, for me to disrespect a guest, / even if one worse off than you arrive, / for every guest and beggar comes from Zeus” (14.41-44).” Theme of Hospitality repeats again Eumeanus is hospitable to Odysseus (in disguise), and attempts to make him comfortable even with his meager means Book 15: Athena tells Telemachus to hurry home. Warns him about the trap that the suitors have set for him. Has his ship drop him off before the city so that he can approach in secret. Odysseus and Eumaeus spend an evening together Book 16: Telemachus arrives at Eumaeus’s hut and then sees his son for the first time in 20 years. They share Eumaeus’s food. When Eumaeus leaves, Athena transforms Odysseus into his real self. They then lay out their plans to defeat the suitors- 108 suitors and ten servants Eumaeus gives Penelope the message- at the same time as Telemachus sailors arrive Plot against Telemachus’s life, even while denying that they mean him harm when confronted by Penelope “I’m not one of the gods. / Why do you compare me to immortals? / But I am your father, on whose account / you are grieving and suffer distress / having to bear men’s acts of insolence” (16. 95-99). Odysseus’ plan is slaughter, but Telemachus is clear about their odds: “Here, you can soon add up / their numbers—from Dulichium there are / fifty two hand-picked young men, six servants / in their retinue, from Same [nearby island] twenty-four, / from Zacynthus twenty young Achaeans, and from Ithaca itself twelve young men, / all nobility” (16.134-40). “Do you believe Athena, / along with Father Zeus, will be enough / for the two of us, or should I think about / who else might help us?” (16.151-54). content:
Chapter 1# Sound beings with the vibration of an object Sound transmitted by a medium Music is part of the world of sound Pitch: Highness or Lowness of Sound# Pitch → Highness or lowness of a sound Sound that has a definite pitch is called a tone Has a specific frequency Vibrations of a tone are regular and reach the ear at regular intervals Tones will sound different with different pitches Interval of an octave - interval between first and last tones of the scale Octave has seven different pitched before arriving at the high note which duplicates the first one 7 tones on the keyboard Added 12 tones are duplicated in higher and lower octaves Distance is known as the pitch range Most music is based on definite pitches Dynamics# Dynamics → Degrees of loudness or softness are known as Loudness or softness affects the type of the sound Italian terms indicate dynamics Ways to indicate dynamical changes Not super precise Tone has a dynamic level - in relation to other tones around the instrument or vocal Tone Color# Tone color or Timbre descriptions Bright Dark Brilliant Mellow Rich Even though instruments might sound the same, the sound that the instrument creates will likely vary Chapter 2# Voices# Singing demands a greater control of pitch and volume Range of singers voice depends on training and physical makeup Professionals usually have a vocal range of about 2 octaves Musical Instruments# Any mechanism other than a voice that produce musical sounds
Most instruments have a wider range than voices
6 categories of music
Woodwind Brass String Percussion Keyboard Electronic Instruments have different sizes for different sound ranges
Instruments are popular based off of the barrier to entry to the general public
Compositions can be written for more than one person and to large orchestras
A diagram of an orchestra and the different sections of the orchestra
String Instruments# Instruments Violin Viola Cello Double Bass All instruments are similar in setup and are made in the same manner Strings have greatest versatility and expressive range Pizzicato → Plucked string Double Stop → Drawing the bow across two strings Can also be with 3 or 4 strings Vibrato → Throbbing expressive tone while vibrating the string using the fingerboard Mute → Veil or muffle the tone Tremolo → Very high-pitched tones Woodwind Instruments# Produce vibrations of air within a tube Traditionally made of wood All have holes along the length of the instrument that are opened or closed by a key mechanism - similar to how the sound of the recorder changes when you cover the holes Woodwinds are very different from each other in terms of tone color Reed- piece of cane Flute- blow over the edge of a mouth hole Brass Instruments# Main instruments Trumpet French Horn Trombone Tuba Mouthpiece - cup shaped funnel that you blow into to play Tube is flared to form a bell at the end of the instruments Mute alters the tone color - can be inserted into the bell Very powerful- used for climaxes in pieces or for powerful. Also given solo passages Percussion# Struck with hand, sticks or hammers or shaken or rubbed Vibrations of percussion instruments are caused by stretched membranes for certain instruments or by plates, bars ,etc. Percussion instruments have been used to emphasize rhythm, build suspense, etc. Oft used by Jazz Musicians Keyboard instruments# Instruments Piano Invented around 1700- perfected by the 1850’s Sound produced by strings and hammers The more that you hit the string, the louder it will be Pedals to sustain the tone, veil tone, sustains some tones, not others Harpsichord 1775- replaced by pianos Harpsichord Organ Accordion Pipe Organ Often used for religious ceremonies Accordian Most used in folk setting Electronic Instruments# Produce or amplify sound via electronic means Invented around 1904 Significant impact on music since 1950 Types Electric piano Electric Organ Electric Guitars Synthesizers Generate, modify, and control sound Can be played via a keyboard 1960’s-70’s smaller, less expensive keyboards developed Allow for the manipulation of sounds MIDI, synthesizers work like a Piano Tape Studio Main tool in the 1950’s Les Paul,etc Including recorded sounds Manipulated sounds Sampling enables composers to hear what their music sounds like using digital technology Digital Audio Workstations → DAWs Chapter 3# Rhythm# Recurring pattern of tension and release Refers to the ordered durations of sounds and silence Beat# Regular, recurrent pulsation Units of time in which all tones are measured Combination of different durations of tones creates the rhythm Meter# All of this is part of meter Some beats feel stronger or more stressed than others Meter → The organization of beats into regular groups Measure or Bar → A group containing a fixed number of number of beats Downbeat → The first or stressed beat of the measure Quadruple meter → 4 beats to the measure, the downbeat is the strongest Jazz and Rock are usually quadruple meter Sextuple Meter→ 6 rather quick beats to the measure Accent and Syncopation# Individual notes are stressed - how they get special emphasis Accent - note is emphasized by being played louder than the notes around it Syncopation → Accented note comes where there one is not expected When an offbeat note is accented Tempo# Tempo is the speed of the beat Fast → associated of energy, drive and excitement Slow → Solemn, lyrical and calm mood Tempo indication is usually given at beginning of a piece in Italian Accelerando - quickening of the tempo Ritardando - becoming slower Chapter 4- Notating Pitch# Horizontal lines on a staff are called ledger lines Seven pitches/tones are: A, B, C, D, E, F, G Repeated over to represent the same tones in higher and lower octaves Other 5 tones of the octave correspond to the black keys of the piano Indicated by sharp sign or a flat sign Natural sign cancel a previous sharp or flat sign Clef is placed at the beginning of the staff Treble clef- used for high ranges Bass clef- used for low ranges Notating Rhythm# Nation does not indicate the exact duration of tones, it shows how long oen tone lasts in relation to others in the same piece Depends on how the note is written- with stems or flags To lengthen a notes, we can make it a dotted note - increases the duration of the note by a half Tue also lengthens the duration of the note- connected by a tie Rhythmic variety - triplet, etc. Notating silence# Notating Meter# Time signature/ meter signature shows the meter of a peice
Appears at the beginning of the staff at the start of a piece
$$ \frac{2}{4} \text{-2 beats to the measure and a quarter note gets 1 beat. The most common meter is} \frac{3}{4}. \text{Quadruple meter is} \frac{4}{4} $$
Chapter 5# Melody# Melody → Series of single tones that add up to add up to a recognizable whole Has direction, shape and continuity Conveys tension and release, expectation and arrival Melodic curve or line Climax - The highest note of a melody Legato → Sung or played in a smooth or connected setup Staccato → May be performed in a short or detached matter Letters commonly used for discussing the segments of the peices lowercase for shorter sections (a,b,etc) Uppercase letters for longer sections (A,B,etc) Melody and Words# Melody expresses the meaning and emotion of the words Melody can evoke feeling in the listeners Chapter 6- Harmony# Harmony refers to the way chords are constructed and how they follow each other Consonance and Dissonance# Consonance → A tone combination that is stable Dissonance → A tone combination that is unstable Tension demands an onward motion to a stable Resolution → Dissonance has its resolution when it moves to a consonance Consonance and dissonance can exist in varying degrees Some or more or less stable than other The Triad# Triad → Most basic chord Harmony- simultaneous tones in music that add support and richness to melody Tonic chord → The main chord of the piece Subdominant chord - the triad based on the fourth note of the scale Dominant chord- built on the fifth note Cadence - means both the resting point at the end of the melodic phrase Broken Chords (Arpeggios)# Broken Chord or Arpeggio - Individual tones of a chord are sounded one after another Chapter 7- Key# Key involves not only a central tone but also a central scale or chord Scale is the basic pitches of a piece of music arranged from low to high The Major Key# The major scale has two kinds of intervals: Half-steps and whole-steps Half-step is the smallest interval traditionally used in western music Whole step is twice as large as the half step The Minor Scale# Consists of seven different tones and an eighth tone that duplicates the first an octave higher Minor scale can begin on any of the twelve tones in an octave Thus, there are 12 minor scales Major and Minor keys# When a piece is based off of a major scale → Major Key When a piece of music is based off of a minor scale → Minor Key To indicate the key of a music - composer uses a key signature The Chromatic Scale# Twelve tones of the octave form the chromatic scale Tones of the chromatic scale same distance apart, unlike major and minor scales Tones are one half-step apart Chromatic scale does not define a key Contribute to a sense of motion and tension Modulation- Change of key# Short pieces of music - single key from beginning to end Longer pieces of music, variety or contrast created by using more than one key Modulation → Shifting from one key to another within the piece Tonic Key# No matter the amount that a piece has been changed, there is usually only one home note Modulation is moving away from the home key, but then eventually returning to the home key Chapter 8- Musical Texture# Musical texture - refers to how many different layers of sound are heard at a time Described as: Dense Thin Thick Heavy Light Monophonic Texture# Monophonic → Having one sound Singing alone Single line with the same pitch in unison makes a stronger sound than singing alone Polyphonic Texture# Polyphonic → Having many sounds Each line of the piece enriches the other Counterpoint → Combining several melodic lines into a whole Round → song in which the same melody is sung or played at slightly different times Homophonic Texture# Homophonic → One main melody accompanied by chords Chords are subordinate to the melody Chapter 9- Musical forms# Form → organization of musical elements in time Techniques that Create Musical Form# Repetition → Creates a sense of unity Contrast → Provides variety Variation → keeps some elements of musical thought while changing others - gives a work unity and variety at the same time Repetition# Appeals to the pleasure we get in recognizing and remembering something Passage of time influences our reaction to repetition Contrast# Forward motion, conflict and change of mood Variation# Some ideas will be retained while others are changed Melody might be restated with a different accompaniment Types of Musical form# ABA Form# Contrast between A and B and then return to AB (Binary form)# Composition made up of two section is in two part form AABB Chapter 10- Musical Style# Style - refers to a characteristic was of using melody, rhythm, tone color The was these elements are combined can result in a total sound that’s unique Musical styles can change from one era to the next History of western art can be divided into the periods: Middle Ages (450-1450) Renaissance (1450-1600) Baroque (1600-1750) Classical (1750-1820) Romantic (1820-1900) Twentieth century to 1945 1945 to the present

Romanticism in Music# About 1820-1900 Franz Schubert, Robert Schumann, Clara Wieck Schumann, Hendel, Dvorak, etc. Continued to use the musical forms of the classical era Emotional intensity was already present in Classical work Romantic music usually have a greater range of tone color, dynamics and pitch Harmonic vocabulary is broader More emphasis on colorful, unstable chords Linked more closely to other arts- literature Characteristics of Romantic Music# Individuality of Style# Expression of the individual and the individuality of self Tchaikovsky, Chopin, Schumann were some of the pioneers of this style Expressive Aims and Subjects# Flamboyance and intimacy, unpredictability, melancholy, rapture and longing Glorification of Romantic love Fantastic and Diabolical Dream of a Witches’ sabbath All aspects of Nature attracted Romantic musicians Subjects drawn from the Middle Ages and Shakespeare Nationalism and Exoticism# Composers create music that express a National Identity Exoticism → Composers drawing on colorful materials from foreign lands Program Music# Program Music → Instrumental music associated with a story, poem or idea Can represent the emotions, characters, and events of a particular story. can evoke the sounds and motion of nature Romeo and Juliet - Tchaikovsky Music matches the mood of the scene Expressive Tone Color# Rich and sensuous sound Timbre is extremely important Romantic orchestra is larger and more varied in tone color than the classical orchestra 100 ish people 20-60 in classical Brass, Woodwind, Percussion take on a more active role Brass Trombones, Trumpets, etc Woodwind Bass Clarinet English horn Piccolo Composers want to blend and combine tone colors Piano vastly improved during the 1820s and 1830s Piano tone became more “singing” Range extended Pianist could produce more sound due to a larger instrument Damper pedal allowed for blend of tones from all registers of the piano Colorful Harmony# Explored new chords/existing chords Emphasized greater emotional intensity, rich, colorful and complex harmonies Chromatic harmony → Uses chords containing tones not found in the prevailing major or minor scale Chromatic scale Add color and motion to romantic music Expanded Range of Dynamics, Pitch, Tempo# Sharp contrasts between dynamics ffff, pppp, etc. More expressiveness- use crescendos, etc Often accompanied by changes in pace Form: Miniature and Monumental# Thematic transformation - change the melody as it returns later in a piece by changing dynamics, etc. Different movements of a romantic work can be linked together through transitional passages Romantic Composers and Their Public# Composers role in society changed greatly during the time of Beethoven Part of the musicians job had been the composition of works for a specific occasion and audience Bach wrote cantatas for weekly church services One of the first musicians to work freelance This image of Beethoven inspired romantic writers Romantic composers were interested in pleasing those around them and being judged fairly by posterity Free artists by necessity rather than choice Many aristocrats could not afford to have court musicians Romantic composers wrote primarily for a middle class audience Citizens expanded dramatically and people want to hear music First half of the nineteenth century witnessed the founding of music conservatories throughout Europe Captured by virtuosity Private music making also increased during the romantic era Piano becomes a fixture in middle class homes Romantic composers came from the social class that was their main audience It was difficult for children to make a living through music Most composers were forced to work at many areas at work Sonata Form# Sonata form → Refers to the form of a single movement Exposition → Themes are presented
Development → Themes are treated in new ways
Recapitulation → Themes return
💡Exposition First theme in tonic (home) key Bridge containing modulation from home key to new key Second theme in new key Closing section in key of second theme Development New treatment of themes; modulations to different keys Recapitulation First theme in tonic key Bridge Second theme in tonic key Closing section in tonic key Coda In tonic key
Exposition# Strong conflict between the tonic key and the new key Bridge or Transition → leads to the second theme Usually a repeat sign at the end of the exposition in order to indicate if it should be played again Development# Most dramatic section of the movement Rapid modulations and the harmonic tension is heightened Themes are broken into fragments or motives Recapitulation# Brings resolution as we hear the first theme in the tonic key Coda# Powerful feeling of conclusion is attained by following recapitulation with another section Coda rounds off a movement by repeating themes or developing them further Always ends in the tonic key Sonata form is exceptionally flexible and subject to endless variation Viewed as a set of principles that serve to shape and unify contrasts of theme and key Symphony No 40# Controlled agitation in opening Persistence of this rhythmic pattern gives the music a sense of urgency Melody is balanced and symmetrical [msedge_TJoiOBqOh1.png](<https://prod-files-secure.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/8147ef02-8109-4add-a936-9c2f026e2ec7/edafeb9c-80df-45b1-9a9c-c95aa23ae7b3/msedge_TJoiOBqOh1.png>) Theme and Variation# Theme and Variations was widely used in the classical period
A basic musical idea (theme) is repeated over and over and is changed each time A

Each variation is unique
Usually same length as the theme Changes of melody, rhythm, harmony, accompaniment, dynamics, or tone color Core melody may appear in the bass or it may be repeated in a diff key Composer might invent an original melody or use someone else
Minuet and Trio# Often used as the third movement in classical symphonies
First appeared at Court of Louis XIV
Movement of a symphony is written for listening, not dancing
It is in triple meter 3/4 ABA form Minuet- A
Trio - B
Minuet- A
Often contains woodwind solos
Minuet is structurally the simplest movement of a symphony or quartet
In many of Beethoven’s works, the third movement is not a minuet but related form called a scherzo Rondo# Rondo → Tuneful main theme (A) that returns several times-alternation with other themes AVACA ABACABA Main theme is usually stated in the tonic key, its return is all the more welcome Rondo form is often combined with elements of sonata form to produce a sonata-rondo Contains a development section like that in sonata form is outlined ABA-development-ABA The Classical Symphony# Greatest contribution of the classical period to orchestral music is symphonies
Haydn = 1-4 symphonies Mozart = 40+ Beethoven = 9 Symphony → Extended, ambitious composition typically lasting between twenty and 45 min. Uses the expanded range of tone color and dynamics of the classical orchestra
Usually consists of four movements that evoke a wide range of emotions through contrasts of tempo and mood Vigorous- Dramatic fast movement
Usually the most dramatic movement Sonata form A lyrical slow movement
Most likely to find broad, songlike melodies here Sonata form: ABA Dancelike movement (minuet or scherzo)
For Haydn and Mozart is generally a minuet and trio which may be in a moderate or fairly quick tempo Varies from courtly dance to a peasant romp or vigorous piece that is not very dancelike Beethoven likes fast, energetic scherzos A brilliant or heroic fast movement
Concluding movement of a symphony by Haydn or Mozart is fast, lively and brilliant but somewhat lighter in mood than the opening statement In most of the classical symphonies each movement is a self contained composition with its own set of themes
A theme in one movement will only rarely reappear in a later movement
Importance of the symphony lasted throughout the twentieth century and into the twenty-first

interest in Bachs music Earned him an international reputation Often visited and played for Queen Victoria Personal life more conventional than most romantic composers Fanny Mendelssohn Hensel# Older Since the 1980s, her works have become more and more performed
At thirteen, in honor of her father’s birthday, Fanny played from memory all the twenty-four Preludes from Bach’s The Well-Tempered Clavier, and at fourteen, composed songs and piano pieces. However, her father limited Fanny’s musical ambitions by saying that as an upper-class young woman she could never aspire to be a professional musician like her brother Felix: “Music will perhaps be his profession, whilst for you it can only be an ornament, never the root of your being and doing.” Even her beloved brother Felix agreed with their father and discouraged Fanny from publishing her compositions. In 1826, two of her songs were published together with four songs by Felix under his name. Years later Felix visited Queen Victoria at Buckingham Palace and accompanied her as she sang a song she thought was by him. After the Queen praised the song, Felix admitted to her that it was composed by his sister. When she was twenty-three, Fanny married Wilhelm Hensel, painter at the court in Berlin, who encouraged her musical activities. The couple’s only child was named Sebastian Ludwig Felix Hensel after Fanny’s favorite composers, Johann Sebastian Bach, Ludwig van Beethoven, and Felix Mendelssohn. In 1831, Fanny became music director and performer at Sunday concerts in the Mendelssohn family mansion, reviving the musicales her parents had hosted years before. Fanny’s concerts were attended by up to 200 invited guests from Berlin’s elite. The works heard included compositions ranging from Bach to Chopin, and guest performers included such famous virtuosos as Clara Schumann and Franz Liszt. In 1846, persuaded by praise from musicians, Fanny wrote in her diary, “I have made up my mind to publish my things.” To Felix she wrote: “I am as afraid of you my brother at age 40 as I was of Father at age 14…1 hope I won’t disgrace all of you through my publishing.” Felix replied giving Fanny his “professional blessing on your decision to join our guild.” Several of her works finally appeared in print under her name, but less than a year later, in 1847 at age forty-one, Fanny died of a stroke.
